awd_titl_txt: Precision Studies of Neutrino Oscillations and Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the Higgs mass has the value it has and why there is no antimatter in the universe. One of the primary areas to search for answers to these and other open questions about the universe, how it came to be, and why it is the way it is, is to focus on a study of the properties of neutrinos and to use what we know and can learn about neutrinos as probes of science Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). Neutrinos are those elementary particles that interact with practically nothing else in the universe. They have no electric charge and were once thought to be massless. Like other elementary particles, they were believed to have an antimatter counterpart, the antineutrino. Moreover, the Standard Model predicted that there were actually three different kinds of neutrinos that were distinguishable through the different interactions that they did undergo whenever there was an interaction. But recent measurements have totally changed our picture of neutrinos. We now know that neutrinos do have a mass and because they do, they can actually change from one type to another. Detailed measurements of these changes as well as others form one of the most promising ways to probe for new physics beyond the Standard Model.

The William and Mary Group is searching for evidence of CP Violation (related to the imbalance of matter and antimatter in the universe) with the NOvA experiment and is studying how neutrinos interact in normal matter with the MINERvA experiment.   The group is also engaged in R&D for DUNE, the next generation, long baseline neutrino experiment with endpoints at Fermilab in Illinois which provides the neutrino beam and the Sanford Underground Laboratory in South Dakota which is home for the detectors.   Presently under test are large detector prototypes called "ProtoDUNEs", which are massive liquid-Argon based detectors called Time Projection Chambers.  The testing is underway at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, and will guide the development of the massive detectors that will be built for DUNE in the next decade.

The William and Mary group is committed to engaging undergraduates in research as a vital component of their undergraduate education.   Beyond promoting science education at the College, the group operates a successful Emerging Scholars  program at a local elementary school. This ten-week, after-school program exposes students who are from communities historically underrepresented in the sciences to practicing physicists and exciting science activities. The program was developed in consultation with the Coordinator for Gifted and Talented Students of the Williamsburg- James City County schools and has grown and been strengthened based on feedback from follow-up discussions with the students and notes from in-session observations by specialists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit 

Particle physics experiments explore Nature at scales ranging from the size of the proton to the size of the universe and are done to find answers to fundamental questions such as: “How does the universe work?”; “How did the universe begin and evolve?”; “Why is there more matter than anti-matter?”

The last question addresses how we are here, if not why. In the early Universe, matter and anti-matter should have been produced in equal quantities, an expectation known as CP-symmetry.  However, if CP-symmetry was true, all the matter and anti-matter would have annihilated leaving only radiation behind. Why didn’t that happen? That is a central question our group is working to answer.

We focus on measurements of neutrinos, the most abundant and mysterious matter particles. They are produced in the Sun, by nuclear reactors, and by particle beams.  Neutrinos interact only via the weak nuclear force, and most matter is nearly transparent to them.  Occasionally a neutrino will collide with a nucleus and produce secondary particles that can be seen in a detector.  Neutrinos come in three “flavors.” The most familiar is the electron neutrino that partners with the electron in weak interactions. The other two flavors are partners of heavier particles called the muon and tau. 

Neutrinos undergo quantum mechanical flavor mixing, or “neutrino oscillations.”  This phenomenon is analogous to when two identical piano strings under slightly different tensions are plucked. The beat frequency that one hears can be used to measure the difference in tension. We observe beat frequencies by looking at how neutrinos change flavors as they propagate. We use those observations to deduce the difference in masses of the neutrinos and how their vibrations mix together. Using neutrinos, we can probe seven of the 25 physical constants in the Standard Model of particle physics.  One of those parameters determines if neutrinos break CP-symmetry.

Summary of outcomes

We worked on three experiments based at Fermilab. NOvA studies neutrino oscillations. MINERvA studies the way that neutrinos interact with matter. DUNE is a multi-purpose experiment in the planning and construction phase. NOvA and MINERvA combined to publish 23 peer reviewed journal articles during the award period. Our group also worked on the DUNE conceptual and technical design reports and on development needed to build the detectors. The award supported 13 undergraduates, 7 graduate students and 2 postdocs. Two graduate students obtained their PhD’s and have taken postdoctoral research positions in the field. 

NOvA

NOvA measures neutrino interactions in two detectors. The near detector measures the energy and composition of a neutrino beam before oscillations, while the far detector, 810 km away, measures the beam after oscillations.  Comparisons of the data between detectors reveal oscillations.  Details of the mixing of neutrinos vs. antineutrinos constrain the mass ordering, the CP violating phase, and the magnitude of the mass splitting and the values of the mixing angles.  During the award period, NOvA measured oscillations of neutrinos and antineutrinos, showing the asymmetry between the two is consistent with zero, meaning the effects of mass ordering and CP-violation may be canceling each other.  More data is required to disentangle the two effects.  NOvA has analyzed about half of its expected exposure and will continue to take data through 2026.  W&M personnel serve as the NOvA co-spokesperson and as an oscillation analysis working group convener.

MINERvA

MINERvA studies neutrino interactions on nuclei, to support oscillation experiments like NOvA and DUNE. Our work focused on inclusive muon neutrino scattering, prediction of the neutrino flux from the NuMI beam, and measurements of neutrino-electron scattering to improve knowledge of the flux. Two PIs, a postdoctoral researcher, and three graduate students worked on MINERvA.

DUNE

DUNE is a multi-purpose experiment that will study neutrino oscillations along with topics such as proton decay and dark matter searches. We worked on the design and simulation of the DUNE experiment, focusing on the near detector and flux predictions for the LBNF beam. We also worked on the design and production of elements of the anode planes and high voltage system of the far detector. One of our group was the co-editor of the near detector conceptual design report.

Broader Impact

During the award, the group was involved in preparing 38 products communicating findings with the community, including peer-reviewed publications, conference proceedings, and talks.  The project provided professional training for students and postdoctoral researchers in computing, big-data analysis, scientific-instrument development, experimental operation, and communication of technical information.  In total, 13 undergraduates, 7 graduate students and 2 postdocs were supported, allowing them to participate in world-class experiments and develop their research skills. Two of the graduate students obtained PhD’s and have taken postdoc positions in the field.  The PIs operated an after-school STEM program at a local elementary school and participated in public outreach events hosted by the W&M physics department.
